header.relationships: Close family, partners, very close friends

body.u: did you enjoy your recent trip to Goddards the home of Noel Terry

yes I thought it was a good trip er it's not a very big house I thought they could have done with a bit more furniture in it and none of the furniture was actually original I don't think because a lot of the furniture was donated to Fairfax House in York because they didn't have any furniture of the period and also because he was erm an avid furniture collector
yes

it was a shame there wasn't more in the house mm I would have liked to have lived in the house I thought it was a very desirable location in York and er I like the arts and crafts style of property had a lovely garden although you would have needed quite a number of gardeners I think to maintain it to that standard
be nice if they could erm buy some furniture that was sympathetic to the period

yes that would give it a bit more character I think I felt it was just a little bit empty also I thought there was going to be more about the chocolate making of Terry's in the house they could have had more photographs and maybe some demonstrations to make it a bit more interesting
yes perhaps some free samples even?

absolutely yes I think it's good to have somewhere else to visit though because we've been to most of the National Trust properties in the area several times before so it's nice to have somewhere a bit different to try for a change
it is I think erm having the er membership encourages you to er visit all the local properties that you would not necessarily visit if you were not a member

yes I think you're right I don't think we'd go as frequently if we didn't have the membership because it is quite pricey especially for a family but I think they're a good day out for a family er if you do have the membership tickets
yes
and when we went to Nunnington Hall which is one of my favourites in this area we were able to take a picnic so that helped keep costs down a little bit
it does but if we didn't have the membership I think we'd be rather restricted in what we could do erm on our leisure trips at the weekend

yes yeah I think one of my favourites in this area is Beningbrough Hall I think the one of the best exhibits there is the laundry room cos I like to see all the Victorian linens from the embroidery that appeals to me
well which one do you prefer? you stated that you erm your favourites are both Beningbrough and Nunnington
erm I think probably Beningbrough is more interesting because I like the er laundry room but Nunnington is nearer and it's usually a bit quieter isn't it?
it is but it is surprising erm that the number of visitors of Nunnington Hall is sixty thousand
I know
despite it being such a secluded location
I was amazed at that er so what was that? it was in the top ten was it?
no it was erm I think it was in the top a hundred
oh the top one hundred mm so which is the best National Trust property that you've ever visited do you think?
yeah so I have been to a number
yeah you've been to quite a lot
in a really good position to
yes had a good
say I think probably erm Huston Manor was one of my favourites the the home of er Disraeli
yes
which we saw on our last holiday
yes
I think er I kind of have a a close association with Disraeli and that period because it has formed part of my studies
mm
I think it's nice to see the environment of which er politicians that you have studied erm live in
yes cos I had never heard of that before
no
no I didn't I didn't know that's where he lived never really thought about it so I was quite pleased to visit it is that a less well-known property?
I think it is I think in some ways it's understated
mm yes and that had a nice garden as well
it does
cos it had well the formal garden and the vegetable garden where
it did
they're actually growing produce so that was quite interesting
I was quite surprised as how big the vegetable garden is and
mm yeah it was wasn't it?
didn't it not have an excess of fifty varieties of apple within
did it?
the same garden and also the fact that it was one a slope must also have
yes
provided technical difficulties
yes it would be more difficult to do wouldn't it? well
did you enjoy your visit there?
yes yes I think one of the things I liked best about visiting these old properties is when they have a really good kitchen I like to see the kitchen's laid out with all the copperware
yes
the pans which was that one? was it
that was Holcombe
was that Holcombe? what was the other one with ha flied house ? what was that where it was besa? oh Hardwick bessa Hardwick Hall
Hardwick yes
that had a really good kitchen didn't it?
it did yes
it had all those moulds for making desserts
it did
I think they were really nice
yes it was a bit of a shame that er whilst they did do demonstrations that due to food hygiene restrictions you're not able to actually taste the the erm products made
oh dear it goes a bit mad sometimes health and safety doesn't it?
I know they're probably worried about someone er being affected by that and would create a massive erm issue
and suing making a claim
yes
yes
are there any more National Trust properties you are planning to visit in the er near or distant future?
I don't think so we've been to quite a few haven't we?
I think one thing that is rather disappointing is that Gladstone's house erm Hawarden Castle
yes
that's not really open to the public that they're it's really just the gardens were open a couple of afternoons a year and the actual property itself is not really accessible
is that because it's privately owned?
yes
yes so is that not such a big house? or is it quite a good size?
no it is relatively big yes
yes
it's surprising in one way
yeah I think York is very well known for its chocolate making
it is

with the Terry family and the Rowntree family and it's a shame that most of it has been taken out of the city and gone overseas now I think it's taken the heart out of York a bit certainly the employment opportunities have been reduced
absolutely

and they were such philanthropists er Quaker families who were doing good works in Victorian days providing employment and social housing and facilities for the workers I don't think we'd really get nowadays do we? well I don't know of any companies that do that now erm I think Bill Gates makes a lot of donations to charities doesn't he?
yes but maybe erm their role in society was to in some ways er counteract the lack of state erm aid that was provided to people because obviously
yes
in times of Terry
yes
erm
Fry's and Rowntree's

Fry's Rowntree's there wasn't really any sort of benefits or welfare system in place so therefore perhaps in certainly in Western Europe and er more economically developed countries there was less need now for
yes
yeah
compared to what there was in the past

yeah I think charity probably takes a different form now in that there's lots of charity shops which when I was younger there was probably Oxfam that's about the only one that I can remember certainly on the high street er there weren't the proliferation of charity shops that you see nowadays
no
also there's lots more erm fundraising events that go on all the time
absolutely
people doing parachute jumps and er that kind of thing cycle rides and er
mm er in some ways people er are a bit too extreme at times
or yes they can be yes
in their ways of raising money for charity
yeah I certainly wouldn't want to do a parachute jump I don't think you could get insured for that do you?
no no I think it's a big risk if anything er happened
yes
to the person
and if something did happen how would you feel if you'd sponsored the person to do that and then they had an accident?
that would be er a bit of an emotional drain
you yeah I mean it seems a bit of a shame really that somebody has to do something like that in order for somebody to give them the money why can't you just give them the money?
mm
or why don't you say I'll pay you not to do it?
yes I think some people see it as a thrill and adventure er
yes
rather than think about the potential consequences
yes so where do you want to go on holiday next year?
well it's er a difficult decision that really er there's er a few places I have in mind
mm
er I would like to see the the Swiss Alps and erm explore the er rich railway heritage of Switzerland
yes

which while it's not very old in the fact that they were relatively latecomers erm to railways but I think they were perhaps er much more adventurous than certain er other railways erm within Europe because I think they've chosen some really steep descents erm so steep that you having to go round in like a er a helter-skelter erm circle
yes they certainly had some technical challenges to get over some of that terrain haven't they?
yes er I think it will be surprising if we do go up to which is the highest
yes
railway station in Europe
yes
also known as the top of Europe
yes
erm how much an engineering triumph it was
yes
to be able to build there so of course erm not today but a few hundred years back
yes did you see the Michael Portillo programme featuring that?
yes
yes
I thought that was a good series
yes have you seen most of them?

I have seen most of them I think there is definitely a lot of and more programmes that he could do I think one thing that they have not covered yet is the Trans-Siberian Railway which I think is an absolute
oh yes
incredible journey which I think people really do cover but the thing is the fact that it takes two weeks to get from erm sort of Moscow St Petersburg to Vladivostok
yes
means that it will be a maybe a ten programme series to look at everything on the way but on the other hand you've got to remember that erm Russia is not as densely populated
no
and obviously the attractions to see may be more sparse
yes is that the Orient Express?
that's not the Orient Express
it's not the Orient Express
the Orient Express is erm from Venice to Istanbul
oh has he done that one?
he hasn't done that one yet no
oh be probably too expensive though would it?
well I think it does cost quite a bit of money to go on that I think it's about er I can't remember yeah I think it's nearly two to three thousand pounds a single journey
mm
it is very expensive but obviously if it's television they've got a lots of funding to do that sort of thing
yes yes do you think they're trying to show things that you might be able to do? whereas if they showed that not many people would be able to avail themselves of that opportunity
it's very true but at least you'd be aware of it for example I don't think most people are erm aware of what it is like inside erm
yes
erm obviously the places is that er you can see on the way can be accessed by normal train routes
yes yes
perhaps not the same route but certainly
yes
erm there is a valid route to take

yes but then once you've seen it on the television you might sa well I've seen it on the television now so I don't need to bother to go and spend the two thousand pounds to do it myself now so it could save you a lot of money
well I'm not sure about that I think seeing on the television is one thing
and going is quite another thing I don't think you get the thrill and the experience
no
of the erm
no I don't
rail travel
no
and the places that you see which presumably will be very idyllic
I'd still like to do it but I think watching it on the television might be the nearest I ever get
although if you want an economy compromise you could go on the North York Railway couldn't you?
North Yorkshire Moors Railway on the erm they've got some nineteen thirties carriages haven't they?
yes they have
where you can have a dining experience
well erm they claim that that is erm in fact better than the Orient Express
in what way?
because the Orient Express is diesel hauled whereas erm
yes
the North York Moors Railway can be steam hauled at times
true I think that would be more atmospheric don't you?
it would but I think it's from a technical point of view one thing is that steam can actually damage the overhead wires
mm
if it gets too close
yes
depending on what wires are made
mm would you be able to realise from inside whether it was diesel or steam? or is it just from an enthusiast's point of view?
I think it would probably be more from an enthusiast's point of view I know if I'm on a train I can tell
mm
that it's er diesel electric or steam
right
but if I couldn't see anything
no
you'll be giving me a bit more of a challenge
yes most people wouldn't probably realise unless you look out of the window
yes
yes when you're on a curve then you can see the steam billowing overhead
yes
I think that looks very attractive doesn't it?
but really the er tell tail signs for an electric is really before you get on you'll see it
right
on the book on the roof of the train whereas
yes
on a diesel you are not going to see that
no some people have said that meals are not really very good value on that service haven't they?
mm well it certainly is a a little bit of an investment
I think it's something that you're only going to do once really for a special occasion possibly
yes
so I think it might be worth it just to have the experience
absolutely
of saying that you've done that and enjoying it and
that's one thing I think about the Venice to something Orient Express
yes
I do at least hope to do it once in my lifetime
really?
just so that I can say I've been on it and
yes
have the atmosphere of it
yes
I must admit I'm not a wholly convinced of the way that cabins are formed on the er kind of overnight sleeper trains
no
I was personally expecting that it would be like a more like a small hotel room
yes
but actually it's erm kind of like a couchette
mm
in the day and then you fold the couchette over and erm and some overhead er
beds come down
beds to form it like that so
yes
it's really more like a bunk bed arrangement
right but do you have to share with people that you don't know?
well I think if you if you go by yourself then you would but if there I think there are cabins for two three and four
for a family
up to six people
yes yeah I think that'd be really good and do you is it a nineteen thirties style or?
erm I think it is yes
is that steam or diesel?
it's it's diesel yes
it's diesel mm
so obviously I they're both very er places with charisma
yes
Venice and
yes
Istanbul I think they're very distinct
yeah I really liked Venice a lot more than I thought I would because I was actually surprised at how clear the water was
yes
I thought it might be erm a bit er dirty or smelly but it was absolutely crystal clear and you could see all the plants sparkling through the water and the fish I thought it was really good
the authorities have done well to keep it like that
yes
but I suppose the tourist influence must provide a lot of money for
definitely
the Bento region
yes yeah I thought it was really a thrill to go on that Grand Canal tour the first day that we were there
yes
we went the full length didn't we?
we did up to
yeah that was really good

one thing that I did see was that erm the Venice authorities are planning to charge people to come into Venice if they do not stay in Venice itself because they are complaining that they are not getting enough money from the tourists to maintain things because if you stay in Venice you have to pay a city tax which is payable to the local authority
I don't think that's a very good idea I think that's a bit mean really that you've got to pay just to go into the city are there any other examples of that?
erm I think that would set a precedent
I don't know of anywhere else you where you've got to pay to go in?
no
I think that's a bit excessive
it is and also you've got to think of the erm other such as people spending money in cafes
yes
and erm
absolutely
gift shops that sort of thing
yes
which obviously they collect erm er
business rates
business rates
yes so
obviously if people didn't shop there
no
they wouldn't be able to tax that
well it would boost the local economy and prices were expensive anyway weren't they
they were
in cafes and ice creams and so on
yes
